oai_dc:dc.dc:title: G T Strong
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: George Templeton Strong (1820 – July 21, 1875) was an American lawyer and diarist. His diary and letters provide a striking personal account of life in the 19th century, especially during the events of the American Civil War. He has been described as "quotable, opinionated, and a careful follower of events."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: John Platner Letter
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: John Strong Platner was born in 1837 in Ontario County, New York, and died Dec. 3, 1868 in Clyde, Wayne County, New York. At age 24, he enrolled at Geneva, New York into the 1st Veteran Cavalry and was commissioned 1st Lieutenant of Company H, on May 1, 1861. On February 24, 1862, he was promoted Major in the 33rd New York Infantry and participated with the 33rd in the Virginia campaigns. He returned to the 1st Regiment New York Volunteer Veteran Cavalry as a Lieutenant Colonel on July 20, 1863 and was promoted Colonel, Chief of Staff for the 1st Regiment on December 30, 1863. In February of 1864, he lead the 1st Regiment at the Shenandoah Valley and the 1st remained in the valley as the Cavalry Division, Army of West Virginia, until the end of the war. He was breveted Brigadier General of U.S. Volunteers for meritorious duty on March 13, 1865 and was honorably discharged with the his regiment at Camp Piatt, West Virginia, on July 20, 1865. These letters show him as a Captain writing from Bug Chestnut, VA
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: John Strong Platner
